block.p: CZECH REPUBLIC: JEWISH CEMETERY -- The government has been sued in the European Court of Human Rights in a dispute over how to preserve a 13th-century Jewish burial ground on the Prague site where an insurance company is building its headquarters. The suit was brought by the Committee for the Preservation of Jewish Cemeteries despite a March agreement between the government and local Jews on encasing the cemetery in concrete, and building above and below it.

KOSOVO: FATAL CLASHES -- Six people have been killed in separate attacks in a sudden surge of violence in the Serbia province. In one incident, three Roma, or Gypsies, were killed when they ran into a booby-trap bomb set outside their home. Kosovo Albanians often accuse Gypsies of having aided Serbian repression of Albanians.

HAITI: POLICE AID CUT -- The United States, which has threatened to cut aid to Haiti if disputed election results are allowed to stand, shut down a training program for the Caribbean nation's fledgling police force.

COLOMBIA: WORK STOPPAGE -- Troops guarded key routes into the capital and demonstrators battled riot police in four provincial cities as 700,000 state workers staged a 24-hour strike against government austerity measures.

SOUTH KOREA: NEW RULES FOR TROOPS -- Washington and Seoul agreed to revise a treaty to give South Korea greater jurisdiction over American military personnel suspected of crimes. Previously, suspects remained in American custody until their trials in South Korean courts ended. Now, they will be turned over to Korean authorities when indicted.

KASHMIR: TERMS OF TRUCE -- Indian officials and leaders of the anti-India militant group Hizbul Mujahedeen agreed to set up negotiating teams to set up the ground rules for a three-month cease-fire announced last week by the militants. These are the first talks between India and the rebels since an insurgency began in 1989.

VIETNAM: AGENT ORANGE -- The United States would like to see private American companies and international organizations take part in a cleanup of Agent Orange in Vietnam and does not intend to do the work itself, said Gary Vest, principle assistant deputy under secretary of defense for environmental security, after meetings with Vietnam officials. He said the sides agreed to consider workshops to address problems from the herbicide sprayed during the Vietnam War, but ''we were not here to discuss a U.S. government cleanup.''

CHINA: WAR GAMES -- China's military is conducting exercises involving 110,000 troops along its coastline opposite Taiwan, some of the largest maneuvers in recent years. Taiwan has complained that training missions by Chinese aircraft over the Taiwan Strait have increased in the past year, making it difficult for its own aircraft to train there.

AFGHANISTAN: TALIBAN GAIN -- The Taliban militia overran most of Ishkamish, in the country's far north, inflicting heavy casualties on Ahmad Shah Massoud's opposition forces, according to spokesmen for both sides. The town sits in a vital supply route between two deployments of the Massoud forces.

ZIMBABWE: LENGTHY FARM OCCUPATIONS SEEN -- One day after President Robert Mugabe announced that black squatters would probably leave many white-owned farms within a month, a government spokesman said the process might take considerably longer. Jonathan Moyo, said the squatters would not leave until two million acres of farmland had been acquired, a process that could take more than a year.

SIERRA LEONE: REBEL'S WIFE SUES -- Lawyers for the wife of the rebel leader Foday Sankoh went to court in London to demand that the British government reveal where he is. The lawyers argued that Mr. Sankoh had not been seen since he was seized at his Freetown residence in May and flown away in a British helicopter. The British government said that Mr. Sankoh was in the custody of Sierra Leone authorities. The Sierra Leone government has not divulged his whereabouts.

NIGERIA: HOSTAGES' RELEASE DELAYED -- Gunmen continued to hold 165 oil workers on two oil rigs well past the expected time of their release because of logistical problems, officials said. A spokesman for Royal Dutch/ Shell said that representatives of the abductors -- armed youths demanding jobs -- had not reached the rigs after agreeing on Wednesday to release the captives.

IRAQ: KUWAIT ACCUSED -- A senior military official denied that Baghdad was holding any Kuwaiti prisoners from Iraq's 1990-91 occupation of Kuwait and accused the emirate of exploiting the issue to keep the decade-old embargo on Iraq in place. Yassin Jassem, spokesman for Iraq's antiaircraft defense, was responding to statements by Kuwait's defense minister that he was ready for direct talks with Iraq if Baghdad admitted holding prisoners.

LEBANON: PROGRESS ON U.N. DEPLOYMENT -- The deployment of United Nations peacekeeping forces throughout south Lebanon moved one step closer, as experts completed their investigation of alleged Israeli violations of Lebanese territory. Only when Beirut is satisfied that there are no more Israeli encroachments will it give the green light to the deployment of peacekeepers.
